thesis.description: Pulp has been made for over fifty years by heating wood chips in the presence of alkali at 1.50-170° C. for several hours. The development of the process has followed along empirical lines and even yet there is little fundamental knowledge of the actual mechanism of the cooking-process. Researches which have been carried on in the past have followedclosely the commercial procedure with the end in view, of correlating cooking condi tions wi th the yield and quality of the pulp. [...]
thesis.creator: Lusby, George Russell.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: Alkali cooking studies.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The nineteenth century was an era of great importance in the establishment of democracy in the United States. The century opened with the election of Thomas Jetferson as president, the first Democrat to be put 1n power. Having but recently obtained its independence, the United States was striving to find the basis tor its future policy of government, internal and external. From that time on there was a rapid growth tn population, territorial expansion and in a more complete severance from European influence. It was a period of momentous changes in government and society trom which America was to emerge as a great world power; a period in which it, as the whole world, was to be transformed by industrialism. [...]
thesis.creator: Ulrichsen, Barbara.
thesis.subject: American poetry -- 19th century -- History and criticism.
English.
thesis.title: Democratic tendencies in American poetry of the nineteenth century.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Modern lite 1s so closely bound up with the progress ot science, that there 1s scarcely a field of human activity not untouched by its influence. Our present health, home, city, national and even international life, alike depend on the material advances made in science during the last century. Thus, we can live in large numbers in cities only because of the advances in medical and sanitary sciences. The cities themselves, with homes oomfortable and convenient beyond the dreams of our grandfathers, depend, in the main, on discoveries in the physical sciences and their applioation by the Applied Sciences. Their industries have been enlarged in scope and efficiency by the application of scientific principles. [...]
thesis.creator: Thompson, Winifred.
thesis.subject: Education, Elementary.
Science -- Study and teaching.
Education.
thesis.title: Preliminary work in science in the junior school.

thesis.description: Lignin is unquestionably one of the most baffling of the naturally occurring organic substances that has attracted the attention of the chemist. Occurring as it does in all woody plants, in grasses, cereals and so forth, and to the extent of about 30% in coniferous trees, it is one of the most abundant of raw materials. Unlike cellulose and rubber, lignin has found no application in industry and the arts. rhus quite apart from the academic interest, the study of the structure of lignin implies an endeavour to find some means for its utilization. [...]
thesis.creator: Tomlinson, George Herbert, Jr.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: The formation of vanillin from lignin sulphonic acids and its relation to the structure of lignin.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: During the past three years a rust of peas has become prominent in Eastern Canada. From a position of obscurity and of purely myoological interest, this rust has rapidly attained a position which is causing considerable concern among growers. The only pea rust described to date on this Continent is Uromyces fabae (Pers.) de Bary, though the possibility ofthe European pea rust, Uromyces pisi (Pers.) Wint., having become established in this country is considered herein. [...]
thesis.creator: Thatcher, Frederick Sidney.
thesis.subject: Plant Pathology.
thesis.title: Studies on the parasitism of uromyces fabae (Pers.) de bary.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Recently men prominent in the public life of Canada and Great Britain have made pronouncements which point to a renewed interest in immigration. The author suspects that frequently neither the speaker nor his audience have very specific knowledge either of the peoples already in Canada or the population requirements of the country. Such literature as exists on this subject is very fragmentary and unscientific for the most part* It is as a contribution to the knowledge in this field that the present study of Germans in Canada is being submitted* The body of the study divides itself naturally into three main sections, each of which is complete in itself* Part I is a general section treating the population structure of Canada, German backgrounds and the distribution of Germans in Canada* The two sections of part II are two case studies of German immigrants in two areas, the first section treating a German group in a rural setting, the second a group in a metropolitan centre.[...]
thesis.creator: Moellman, Albert.
thesis.subject: Canada -- Emigration and immigration.
German Canadians.
thesis.title: The Germans in Canada : occupational and social adjustment of German immigrants in Canada.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The gradual increase in complexity of processes from the lower to higher forms of living things is perhaps nowhere more evident than in the methods by which animals reproduce their kind. From the simplest unicellular unit with its obvious reproduction by budding, to the higher mammal with its complicated arrangements for fusion of male and female elements, and for the care of the resulting gamete, there is a gradual increase in specialization. This is readily seen in the mechanisms which have made possible the remarkable coordination of the various activities of the living body, and it is in this connection that the hormones have been demonstrated to be of great importance in the vertebrates. [...]
thesis.creator: McKeown, Thomas.
thesis.subject: Biochemistry.
thesis.title: The hormones, and the nutrition of the offspring before and after birth.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The identity of a sawfly found seriously defoliating ornamental pine trees in the Montreal district has been established as that of Diprion simile Htg., an insect of Europeanorigin. Although this saw fly appears to have a rather restricted range in central and northern Europe, it is closely associated, and has often been confused, with Diprion pini L.,one of the most important pests of conifers in Europe. [...]
thesis.creator: Monro, Hector Alexander Urquhart.
thesis.subject: Hymenoptera.
Zoology.
Sawflies.
thesis.title: The ecology of the pine sawfly Diprion simile Htg.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The purpose of this thesis is to determine the status ot physical education in the Public Elementary and Secondary Schools in the Provinces of Canada. The information 1s arranged under two heads as follows: a) Qualifications and status of teachers of physical education. b) Requirements in, and programme of physical education in the Elementary and Secondary Schools of the provinces. [...]

thesis.description: Gamma ketonic acids of three distinct series have been prepared and their behavior in certain characteristic reactions determined. It has been shown that there is no relationship between the kind of groups present in these acids and their structures. To illustrate this, the action of methyl magnesium iodide and of acetyl chloride has been studied in detail. In the most highly branched series -the acrylio acids- the resemblance of the lactols to triphenyl carbinol has been noted. To account for the action of acetyl chloride, in the other two series, a mechanism for the reaction has been proposed and discussed. [...]
thesis.creator: Normington, James Brown.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: The condensation of gamma ketonic esters with aromatic aldehydes; ringchain tautomerism in gamma ketonic acids.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: This work treats freeudom of opinion ln France and-Canada. Freedom of assembly; freedom of expression, by such means as speech, press, radio, theatre and cinema; and freedom of association,for trade unions as weIl as polltlcal groups; are compared in the two countries. The conclusion based on this comparative study Is that there is much more freedom of opinion in France than in Canada and that the latter would do weIl to respect in a like manner the principles essential to a free expression of opinions.[...]
thesis.creator: Owen, George R. W.
thesis.subject: Liberty.
France -- Politics and government.
Civil rights -- France.
Civil rights -- Canada.
Canada -- Politics and government.
thesis.title: La liberté d’opinion : une étude comparée des libertés publiques en France et au Canada

thesis.description: The major portion of this paper 1s a taxonomic study of the parasitoidal subfamily Joppinae (Family Iohneumon1dae). Their hosts are species of the family Noctuidae and many of these are of eoonomic importance in the prairie provinces. A taxonomic study of the western joppines, therefore, may be of value 1n biological control work. The methods of increasing the natural efficiency of parasitoids are reviewed, as well as the factors that modify or nullify attempts at control. [...]
thesis.creator: Peck, Oswald.
thesis.subject: Entomology.
thesis.title: Some Ichneumonidae of Alberta.

thesis.description: Lignite humic acid, isolated from Ontario lignite and purified carefully, was used in a series of experiments involving the preparation of thirteen variously methylated and acetylated derivatives. The results show that lignite humic acid has the expanded empirical formula [...]
thesis.creator: Plunguian, Mark.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: The preparation properties and structure of humic acids : Part I. The properties and structure of lignite humic acid. Part II. The preparation properties and structure of sugar humic acid.

thesis.description: Piaget's studies of the child's intellectual development are submitted to critical review and evaluation. The clincial method which he has applied in this fie1d is analyzed and tentatively accepted as a new approach to child study. The central hypothesis of the author is that child thought is qualitatively different from that of the adult: he calls this thought "ego-centric". The author postulates that ego-centric thought is incommunicable because it is not socialized and that it evolves in accordance with the growing need into the logical thought of the adult. This ego-centrism results in transductive reasoning, intellectual and moral realism and pre-causality. These doctrines are found to be biased by the conditions of the experiment, the choice of subjects and the emphasis on the social factor at the expense of physical experience. Piaget's research supplies a mass of data and a suggestive interpretation of the nature of child thought.
thesis.creator: Dodds, Margaret Ruth.
thesis.subject: Psychology.
Piaget, Jean, 1896-1980.
Child psychology.
thesis.title: A critical review of Piaget’s contributions to child psychology.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: This thesis treats of the fundamental principles of regenerative braking as applied to electrically propelled cars and locomotives. It discusses the most important systems used.The introductory chapter outlines briefly the history of the development of the problem. Chapter 11 deals with the advantages and disadvantages of this method of braking, shows its possibilities on level and mountain lines and gives the practical results obtained from its adoption on certain railroads. Chapter III describes the fundamental characteristics and requirements of the four principal systems and very particularly the direct current system. [...]
thesis.creator: De Angelis, Marius L.
thesis.subject: Electrical Engineering.
thesis.title: Regenerative braking of electric cars and locomotives : a study of its fundamental principles and applications.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The present investigation deals with the study of the variable conditions - temperature, pressure, concentrations, catalysts, duration of reaction, structure of wood, etc. - which influence the course of the sulphite process for the manufacture of paper pulp from wood. Under mechanical conditions is included pre-treatment of the wood with a view to bringing about controlled conditions of penetration of the cooking reagents into the wood. [...]

thesis.description: Before proceeding with the study of the electrical stability of a power system, it is necessary to determine the impedances of the various parts of the system. This will makepossible the calculation of the current which will flow in any branch circuit due to a difference of potential applied between the ends. The impedances must be expressed in terms of resistances and reactances in order to determine the phase relationships between the voltages impressed and the currents produced. [...]

thesis.subject: Electrical Engineering.
thesis.title: Electrical power system stability and experimental measurement of synchronus machine constants.

thesis.description: In elementary texts, chemistry is defined a.s the study of the transformations which matter undergoes. Early chemistry, indeed, concerned itself entirely with the properties of matter, and methods for effecting its transformation. Soon, however, attention was focused on the actual mechanism of reaction and it was found necessary to consider not onlymaterial changes, but accompanying energy changes. [...]

thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: The kinetics of the homogeneous thermal decomposition of diethyl ether at high pressures and other gas reactions.

thesis.description: The study of reaction rates, especially of homogeneous unimolecular ones, has constituted one of the most active fields in physical Chemistry in the last few years. Progress in thissubject began with the replacement of thermodynamic methods, which have no connection with rates, by the use of kinetics and statistical mechanics as a means of interpreting the phenomena met with. [...]

thesis.description: The following investigation was undertaken in connection with theCanadian-American Relations Study launched by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. The object of this monograph is a consideration of those attitudes of Canadians to the United States which have secured definition through the attempt to build up a distinctive national life in Canada. The problem has been approached from two different though complementary points of view. [...]

thesis.description: The short story represents one of the most interesting paradoxes in literature; for while it is one of the oldest of literary forms, it is also one of the most recent. The art of brief narration is as old as the Book of "Ruth," the "Cupid and Psyche" of Apuleius, "The Matron of Ephesus" of Petronius, and "The Pardoner's Tale" of Chaucer; and yet it is as new as Poe and Maupassant, as Chekhov and Katherine Mansfield, as Anderson and Hemingway; as new, in fact, as the latest product of the experimental magazine. [...]
thesis.creator: Blumenthal, Estelle Helen.
thesis.subject: English.
thesis.title: Some recent tendencies in the short story (1914-1934).
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: During the last few years many bacteriologists havebecome increasingly interested in the changes that take placein bacteria and bacterial colonies during growth. In purecultures the appearance of colonies which differ markedly incertain clearly defined characters from the normal type havebeen repeatedly observed. This phenomenon, which is termed'dissociation' for reasons stated below, has been studied ina certain group of acid-fast bacteria - the Mycobacteria.

thesis.title: Colonial dissociation of saprophytic mycobacteria.
